comment._content:
"A plaque on the front corner reads FP 22 Ft."
This is probably to remind the Fire Brigade that there is a Fire Hydrant 22 feet away.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: I am guessing it is Fire Point Here is one in Norfolk, UK with feet and inches. www.leafdigital.plus.com/pics/norfolk4/img_1304.jpg Modern ones are called Fire Hydrants with a big H sign. commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Fire_Hydrant_Sign_on_Houg...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Looks as if you're absolutely right - it's Fire Point! There's a range of Belfast Fire Point signs here: www.geograph.ie/search.php?i=27920032
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: First a drought, then a flood! Geograph Ireland has a great potential. Waterford already has 88 photos in square S6012 www.geograph.ie/gridref/S6012 but Passage West W7668 has none yet.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Classical building next door to no 99 is the Custom House. That's the main entrance in the pic. The Waterford GPO is further along in the same building. Interesting to see the new stone work in the 2nd from left  top floor window of the custom house. This was part of the damage inflicted on the building during the Civil War siege of Waterford 1922 when the building was occupied by anti treaty forces and fired on by Free State forces from across the river.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Interesting indeed! I've amended the description above to reflect your information about the Custom House...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
